description: Introductory workshop in writing poetry, short fiction and nonfiction for love of the written and spoken word. Not for English major credit. Not for English major or English (Creative Writing) major credit.
Introduction to the pleasures and power of poetry, exploring elements drawn from high-points of English poetry, and the lives and works of major poets. (Duplicates credit in ARLT 101g)

course_name: Los Angeles: the City, the Novel, the Movie
description: An exploration of the culture, vibrance, heritage, mythology, variety, and pathology of a city that was born in hopes and captured the worlds imagination. Duplicates credit in ARLT 101g.
Close study of Shakespeare's plays and poems to introduce his language, stagecraft, literary "genius," social and literary contexts, precursors and rivals, and legacy.
Introduction to theory and practice of literary study.
Intensive reading of major writers to 1800.
Intensive reading of major writers, 18001950.
Intensive reading of representative writers.
Introduction to major forms, styles and theories of narrative, with attention to characterization, plot, genres, ethics, empathy, perspective, audience and social conditions.

course_name: Introduction to the Genre of Fiction
description: An introduction to the close reading of fiction and the understanding of the genre as an aesthetic and historical phenomenon.
Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing narrative in fiction and literary non-fiction
Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing prose fiction.
Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing poetry.
Techniques and practice of creative nonfiction writing, including genres such as lyric essay, memoir, personal narrative and/or scientific, medical, nature, culinary and travel writing.
Practical course in relations between editing and the creative process in fiction, poetry, and exposition

course_name: Women in English and American Literature after 1800
description: Women as writers and as subjects, with special emphasis on feminist and liberationist traditions and on changing female images after 1800.
Novels, stories, essays, poems, and plays written in and about California from the Gold Rush to the present.
Study of prose written in English since 1945, principally fiction of the past two decades.
Study of poetry written in English since 1945, with special emphasis on the last two decades.
An examination of how literature and related arts intersect in a particular cultural milieu. Selected topics.
A practical course in composition of prose fiction.
A practical course in poetry writing.
Prerequisite: English 405 and/or consent of instructor.
Selected studies in the non-dramatic literature of Renaissance England, with emphasis on Sidney, Spencer, and Shakespeare.
Major history plays, comedies, and tragedies.
American poetry and prose to the Civil War with special attention to Irving, Cooper, Poe, Hawthorne, Emerson, Thoreau, Melville, and Whitman.
American poetry, fiction, and drama since World War I with special attention to Eliot, Frost, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, O'Neill, Stevens, Faulkner, and Nabokov.

Development of the poetry, essay, short story and novel of the Chicano and Latino peoples of the United States, with particular emphasis on the differentiating characteristics between the multiple cultures that constitute the Latino populations.
Survey of Asian American literature from the earliest time to the present; development of prose, poetry, and novel.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
Selected problems in literary history and criticism.
Individual research, reading, writing and project development as a senior capstone experience in the study of narrative.
Studies in the works of one or more authors, or in the development of a theme or genre.

course_name: History of Literary and Cultural Theory
description: The assumptions and practices of major theorists and theoretical schools from Plato to literary modernism.
Studies in poetry and patronage, the popular tradition in literature and drama, the social and sexual dynamics of comedy, historical and cultural uses of genres, among other topics.

Plays for the stage shall be written using public-domain poetry and prose as inspiration and source material, complemented with exploring poetry, prose, and varied dramas as context for the student writer. Students should be well-versed in literature, and have written in one or more genres.
Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

course_name: Practicum in Teaching English and Narrative Studies
description: Practical principles for development of effective teaching within the disciplines of English, Creative Writing, and Narrative Studies. Intended for teaching assistants in English.
Studies in Empire and Commonwealth literatures, post-colonialism, American hemispheric connections, African-American discourse, Asian American writers, dialects and the folk, and other topics.

course_name: Introduction to Literary Editing and Publishing
description: Comprehensive introduction to the MA degree and its range of study, focusing on elements of the craft of editing and the literary marketplace.

course_name: The Editorial Experience: The Craft of Publication
description: An intensive workshop in applied English, coordinating literary analysis with editing and publication, including relationships with authors; academic and trade presses; journals; editing and design.

course_name: The Nonfiction Experience: A Literary-Editorial Focus
description: Topics on literary and popular forms: profile portrait; science writing; food writing; place and travel; memoir; and personal essay; with venues for publication.
Introduction to skill sets needed to enter the profession; development of student interests as they fit in the literary landscape.

course_name: Internship in Editing and Publishing: Eloquence and Ethics
description: Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom.
Issues and theory of studying literature in relation to history, science, politics, psychology, religion, sociology, media, the visual arts, and other disciplines.
Studies of major and minor, canonic and non-canonic writers.
Theories of race and ethnicity, cultural imperialism, discourse of power and class, literatures of the Americas, and other topics.

course_name: Seminar in Film Theory and Medium Specificity
description: Explores the way film has been theorized in relationship to traditional media that preceded it and electronic media that followed.
Study of conventional and experimental works of creative nonfiction, from memoir to poetry, criticism and scholarship, focusing on issues of form, ethics, style and audience.
Seminar. Studies in fiction form and function or critical theory.
Intensive practicum in advanced level fiction writing, intended to develop high level creative compositional ability. Open only to Creative Writing PhD degree candidates.
Seminar. Studies in poetry form and function or critical theory.

course_name: Theories and Practices of Professional Development I
description: A structured environment in which to craft a research project, write a dissertation prospectus, and define areas of professional expertise. Graded CR/NC. Recommended preparation: passage of screening exam. Not available for degree credit.

course_name: Theories and Practices of Professional Development II
description: This two-credit course helps ABD students craft their professional identities and placement materials as they make the transition from graduate school to their academic position. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit.

course_name: Academic Writing: Journal Articles and Dissertation Chapters
description: Academic writing workshop focused on producing dissertation chapters and revising seminar papers for publication.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. GRADED CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit upon acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
